website_summaries.verdict: Gives you the basic knowledge to go on a simple camping trip and the confidence to protect yourself should something go wrong.
pros: Full of helpful survival tips and plenty of informative diagrams
Information is presented concisely with clear instructions
Topics range from how to set up camp, dangerous plant identification, and multiple DIY animal traps
Canterbury includes pros and cons, as well as his preference for many of the recommended items in his book
cons: Lack of photos in tree and plant section makes them harder to identify in real life

customer_reviews.title: Um.... No.
customer_reviews.text: Not a lot of Bushcraft technique taught. Things were generally glossed over and if you packed everything that was recommended to take with you you would have more in your pack than you have in your home. I was hoping for some very primitive detailed information and the simply fell short.
customer_reviews.author: William S.

customer_reviews.title: Very disappointed. The information is general
customer_reviews.text: Very disappointed. The information is general, not very clear or concise, hard to follow and woefully lacking illustrations. Cover design was great and I judged this book by its cover when buying it. Don’t do that.
customer_reviews.author: N2XE

customer_reviews.title: In Case You Didn't Know - Don't Let A Dead Tree Fall On You
customer_reviews.text: There was really very little information you probably don't already know but if you need the very basic equipment list for camping (almost half the book) this is for you. It gives all you could ever want to know about what you need to pack in your backpack for camping but goes over other basics (like trapping) in a cursory manner and with expectations that you have a camping supply store nearby to purchase a ready made trap. I was really disappointed.. There was a very long discourse on how fire is achieved and the science behind it. I think there might have been a bit of a struggle finding enough material.
customer_reviews.author: KellyBee

customer_reviews.title: Accurate, but not particularly detailed
customer_reviews.text: I'm not sure what the target audience for this book might be. It's a broad-based overview of outdoor stuff and skills, broad enough to cover most topics, but brief enough that a) it's not 15,000 pages long and b) there's probably not enough detail on any topic for a newbie to become enlightened. It's not that the author is wrong -- and he clearly knows his stuff -- it's just that he doesn't seem to have struck a balance such that one could pack this book in a bug-out-bag and end up OK.
customer_reviews.author: me-not-my-employer

customer_reviews.title: Great diagrams and Amazon is selling for $7 under MSRP
customer_reviews.text: There are so many things I love about this 1) quality and cover texture this should almost fall in a category between hrs back and paperback it's one of the most well made paperbacks I've seen 2) the wide array of survival topics that are covered 3) the book uses diagrams in almost all its explanations so if you really needed to use this info in the wilderness you would have a diagram to follow to make sure you were doing it right 4) and best of all PRICE!! I paid $10 and as pointed out in my last photo msrp for this book is &16.99 :)!!!
customer_reviews.author: Casteel

customer_reviews.title: Very lacking in useful information and illustrations
customer_reviews.text: This is more of a "list of things to bring" rather than how to use what's available. Like other reviewers, I am pretty disappointed with the lack of illustrations and diagrams. There is a whole chapter on traps, but it's just a few paragraphs about how traps are good, you should bring some. There is one page that shows three shelters you can build, and it's the most useless thing I have ever seen. I don't recommend this book to anyone who is interested in bushcrafting.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: A Good Beginner's Guide To Bushcraft
customer_reviews.text: Dave Canterbury is a very well known and respected outdoorsman. The Bushcraft 101 volume is a good read for those beginning their bushcraft journey. It is not the best publication on the subject, but it is concise and instructional. One thing lacking is the amount of pictures or illustrations. In my opinion, Mors Kochanski's book on Bushcraft is the best, describing in detail the use of knives and tools, as well as other skills needed for the budding bushcrafter. <iframe style="width:120px;height:240px;" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" src="//ws-na.amazon-adsystem.com/widgets/q?ServiceVersion=20070822&OneJS=1&Operation=GetAdHtml&MarketPlace=US&source=ac&ref=tf_til&ad_type=product_link&tracking_id=infohutt-20&marketplace=amazon&region=US&placement=1772130079&asins=1772130079&linkId=58e34c85615519660fc8babecf3af690&show_border=true&link_opens_in_new_window=true&price_color=333333&title_color=0066c0&bg_color=ffffff"> </iframe>
customer_reviews.author: Outdoors

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed. I expected better
customer_reviews.text: Disappointed. I expected better. The book went from stating the obvious to not giving near enough detail to be helpful. Also not nearly enough pictures/diagrams. Avoid.
customer_reviews.author: RJ Corey

customer_reviews.title: good buy
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my father for Christmas, I had never heard of it but it seems like something right up his alley. The second he opened the package he was like "how did you know, this is the best book in the must have." Since that I've gotten to look it over and he tells me lots of awesome tid-bits. I would definitely recommend for the man in your life or even the woman who is interested in outdoorsy survival stuff.
customer_reviews.author: H. HunTop Contributor: Baby

customer_reviews.title: Solid Introduction to the Basics
customer_reviews.text: After reading this book I feel much more informed about how to handle things if I were to choose to try to camp in a bare minimum survival situation. Bought this after my buddy mentioned wanting to do nature hikes and stuff just to look into the idea, and since finishing this book I lent it to that same friend to read. I'm not saying that this is the only book you'll need on the subject but it felt like the best intro to the topic there could be.
customer_reviews.author: Dbell42

customer_reviews.title: Very useful
customer_reviews.text: The product arrived on time and I have read about 40 or so pages so far. It has a lot of useful information and helps a beginner like me tremendously. I would recommend to highlight some of the important information to help it stick out more. Chapter 1 focus on your pack. Chapter two focus on tools. Chapter 3 focus on ropes and cordage weapons. Chapter 4 is about containers and cooking tools. Chapter 5 is about coverage while chapter 6 is Combustion. That is all just part one and then you also have part two which talks more about what to do while you’re in the bush. Overall very useful product would recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Pelle F.

customer_reviews.title: This is a great place to start.
customer_reviews.text: I've read most of this book and it is a very comprehensive reference for bushcraft learning if you're the rank novice or an experienced woodsman. It covers the basics of everything you may need to know about taking care of yourself in the bush from shelter building to fire making to equipment to navigation to trapping/processing game to tree identification. There are four different appendices at the end for further reference. You can get a box set with this, the advanced bushcraft book and the hunting/trapping book for not much more than two. It's worth the investment. Dave Canterbury is world reknown for a reason.
customer_reviews.author: NotMyRealName

customer_reviews.title: Awesome Book
customer_reviews.text: Although I have not read the whole book cover to cover, I say as a Marine Veteran who’s has been trained on a few pieces of this material, it is cool and useful. I was worried about many nay sayers who said there was little details and fit for a coffee table piece, but in my opinion that is not so. I think there is an abundance of life saving information for beginner to novice outdoor understanding and experience. My only think is now I seen the illustrated version and wish I had bought it instead, because that would be helpful in some instances.
customer_reviews.author: J

customer_reviews.title: A lot of examples not shown
customer_reviews.text: The book describes in detail what the author is talking about, but I still find it hard to visualize. The previous editions must of had example pictures because there are references to look at following examples that aren't features in the book. I see it throughout the book and yet there are no accompanying pictures. If I didn't have an internet connection to look up examples a lot of this book would be useless to me. What is shown is helpful, but this book would not receive a recommendation from me in it's current edition.
customer_reviews.author: Dennis V. Rueda

customer_reviews.title: Better decoration than text
customer_reviews.text: This is an attractive book and it has a nice aesthetic layout to it. I know it says 101 indicating a beginner level but, it's pretty fluffy on actual information or details even in that light. Likely if you have almost ANY outdoors experience you will flip through this and be done with it in less than a half hour. I feel like this is a better book for decorating a "cabin" or contributing to an "outdoorsy" deco style by adorning a shelf or table than it is for teaching any real appreciable skills. If you have ZERO knowledge of the outdoors this book will be of benefit to you.
customer_reviews.author: Craig M. Kimmel

customer_reviews.title: Get this if you want to be disrespectful of wildlife
customer_reviews.text: Extremely disappointed about all the info on trapping, which is totally unnecessary. True outdoorsmen and women don't use traps. It's really, really barbaric. Google leg hold traps and take a look for yourself.
customer_reviews.author: JL

customer_reviews.title: Best book on the topic hands down
customer_reviews.text: Dave Cantabery the guy knows his stuff. This is the 3rd copy of bushcraft 101 I have owned. I gave my other copies away to camping buddies over the years to help them expand there skill sets. From bass survival to advanced wilderness living Bushcraft 101 has the info you need, explained in manner that any one can comprehend(the illustrations don’t hurt). If your in to the outdoors or are looking for the perfect gift for some one who is you should definitely consider Bushcraft 101.
customer_reviews.author: The Saxon

customer_reviews.title: Snooze-fest
customer_reviews.text: I think I made the mistake of judging this book by its title and cover. It’s honestly a real snooze-fest. Really just a glorified gear list with with few practical wilderness skills or tricks of the trade. You will learn more camping with your dad on the weekend than what is contained in this book. Very disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Mark R. Messier

customer_reviews.title: Good starting point.
customer_reviews.text: I have not yet finished the book but I have read quite a bit of it. (Not bragging). But from what I have read so far it has been very informative. As I have seen a lot of other comments on this book, it really is more of a starting point. It describes the basics and kind of points you in the general direction. You will defiantly need do further research into the different subjects the book touches on. But overall the book contains some good information and I have enjoyed reading it so far.
customer_reviews.author: Alan

customer_reviews.title: Great book for beginner
customer_reviews.text: If you are going to engage in the practice of bushcraft, there are few teachers out there who have the experience and skill level of Dave Canterbury. This is a GREAT book for the beginning bushcrafter. Contains information that is the basis for the elevation of other skills that will be needed later on. It's a great read. Dave is a very articulate author and the text is very explanatory. Buy this book and take it with you out into the wilderness, you will not regret it.
customer_reviews.author: Gary

customer_reviews.title: Extremely basic survival, left out a lot of critical skills
customer_reviews.text: Leaves out a lot of critical skills, basically reading material for yuppies who are contemplating renting a hotel room in Maine with out room service 😂
customer_reviews.author: jesse mullen

customer_reviews.title: Good for anyone interested in the outdoors.
customer_reviews.text: I can't say enough good things about this book. Whether you are experienced in the outdoors or a novice; a hunter or weekend hiker; you will learn something from this book. I've been a fan of Dave Canterbury for several years and I appreciate his simple traditional approach to spending time in the woods. This is not a survival book though he does touch on those subjects. This is a book about how to get out in the wilderness and enjoy creation. I recommend this for anyone interested in the outdoors. One recommendation though. Get the hard copy. Electronic copies for this book make it hard to reference when needed. Much easier with a hard copy.
customer_reviews.author: Brian E. Baker

customer_reviews.title: Meh
customer_reviews.text: A lot of filler in here imo. It has some useful info but its geared more towards boy scout aged campers I think. I was expecting more than I got in terms of useful outdoor/bushcraft tips and tricks. Covers fires and shelters fairly well, but I didn't find anything new or really ground breaking. Maybe my expectations were off. If I had a 12 year old that was interested in this stuff, this might be the book. But for adults who have camped and already know about fires/crude shelters/etc, I'd look elsewhere.
customer_reviews.author: J. Sullivan

customer_reviews.title: A little to early on the learing curve of Bushcraft
customer_reviews.text: If you already have a good step up on Bushcraft this is not the book for you. It truly is 101 level. Maybe even a introductory level. If you don't know yet how to start a fire in the woods or build a small shelter then maybe this book is for you. I'm going to give my wife this book to read, she will glean some information out of it, so it is not useless just a very early stage of the Bushcraft learning level. That's the only reason I give it a four star, what is in the book is good info though.
customer_reviews.author: Mikey B.

customer_reviews.title: Not worth it
customer_reviews.text: I just don’t know where the high ratings came from. A lot of fluff but not many details. The pictures are adequate but not sufficient. If I had to choose a book to take into the Wild, it would not be this one.
customer_reviews.author: Will Rushing

customer_reviews.title: Interesting book
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this book as a gift for a scout interested in wilderness survival. This looks to be a very interesting and thorough book, covering gear and tools needed, as well as information about using what is at hand. There is a little of everything in it with lots of helpful tips and I actually picked up some new tidbits just lightly reading through it before wrapping. Perfect for a young scout and wilderness weekends.
customer_reviews.author: Been There Done That

customer_reviews.title: Need more diagrams and photos
customer_reviews.text: Not enough diagrams explaining what's what and what goes where. Yet there is so much room for them. No photos of edibles or different trees.
customer_reviews.author: Mari

customer_reviews.title: This is a good book for people with some experience and more
customer_reviews.text: I read most of the reviews befor I bought this book. This is a good book for people with some experience and more. I got it for my own learning. It never hurts to see what more you can learn. Needless to sa I ended up buying the hole group in this line. I spend September - November in the Green Mountain. Not in the parks, in the North East Kingdom. There is nothing there and if your not carful you can end up in Canada. Get the book and the rest of them.
customer_reviews.author: Jay Laurie

customer_reviews.title: Not detailed enough to be useful
customer_reviews.text: Much better books out there on the subject. Advanced bushcraft sucks too. His trappings book is better and I haven't read the med book yet.
customer_reviews.author: Joshua

customer_reviews.title: Ate too many edibles - apocalypse
customer_reviews.text: I got super stoned and thought the apocalypse was coming... totally forgot i even ordered this until a bunch of survival supplies, seeds, bincoculars, compas, hand crank radio, potable water straws came primed to the house
customer_reviews.author: carly

customer_reviews.title: amazing. This book was just packed with wisdom and ...
customer_reviews.text: Wow, amazing. This book was just packed with wisdom and knowledge of the outdoors. I really liked that were so many primative skills. Knowledge passed down from native americans to the early frontiersmen allowed people to inhabit and flourish on this land for thousands of years without even modern tools. With the knowledge in this book and a good book on foraging wild edibles in northern new england, I bet I could walk out into the woods with a pack on my back and never have to return.
customer_reviews.author: randall oliverTop Contributor: Hydroponics

customer_reviews.title: Dave Canterbury is great at bushcraft skill and I've watched TONS of his ...
customer_reviews.text: Dave Canterbury is great at bushcraft skill and I've watched TONS of his videos. Want to eventually take one of his classes but this book will have to do for now. A lot of this book can be found on his Youtube channel but can't take Youtube with you when there's no cell service so get the book!
customer_reviews.author: biff101

customer_reviews.title: It's a "101" book (the target audience is the novice)
customer_reviews.text: If you're just getting into bushcraft, you won't be going wrong with this book. Lots of good, basic info. I would say between this, Mors Kochanski's book, and maybe a Backpacker's Field Manual, you got a solid basic library for getting into the wilderness (yes, there will be duplicate info between all of those but you're going to get that no matter what once you have two or more books of any bushcraft title). For foraging, hunting, fishing, all that? I would get books specifically dedicated to those topics and for the area(s) you plan to be in. Youtube will help you sort out any other specialty needs.
customer_reviews.author: Jose S

customer_reviews.title: loaded with useful info for the beginner and moderate bushcrafter
customer_reviews.text: book has proper cover & binding to be your tramping companion. loaded with useful info for the beginner and moderate bushcrafter. well written in easily understandable english my 12 yr old great nephew understands but a good book even the most experienced can learn something from. this book should be a mandatory read for any young adult prior to driving lessons and hunting licenses. the info it contains could save a life. it will be in every stocking i stuff this year.
customer_reviews.author: donald  smith

customer_reviews.title: but at least it had some good basic info
customer_reviews.text: I was expecting more visual aid from this book, but at least it had some good basic info. It doesn't show many primitive skills though, and I was hoping it would. It talks more about what to buy for survival and basics of how to use it, instead of going into detail about teaching basic survival skills like how to find water and process water correctly et. cetera. They cover trapping though and some other neat stuff. It's not a waste, just not the source I was looking for.
customer_reviews.author: Jose

customer_reviews.title: Enjoyed it very much!
customer_reviews.text: I do not have a need for this sort of book, for some time. I've been a bush dweller, outdoors traveller internationally for most of my life. Picked this recommendation for folks I guide Backcountry, and delighted with it. A bit weighted to Eastern USA - however this is useful for the common starting point to conversation on the infinity of topics about thriving in the bush, Backcountry. Cudos for mentioning Mors as well!
customer_reviews.author: R. Goodson

customer_reviews.title: Lacks enough illustrations to make it usable
customer_reviews.text: 1/3rd the way through it, and bleh .... could use lots more illustrations. I write military technical manuals for a living and this book made me very aware of the need for good illustrations (actually, this book fails to illustrate hardly at all). Unless you know the material (which means you don't need this book) then it is kind of non-usable.
customer_reviews.author: Tim little

customer_reviews.title: Not very good
customer_reviews.text: Half the book is more about what to put in a backpack and WAY outdated.
customer_reviews.author: matthew hafer

customer_reviews.title: A great little 5 "C's" for beginner's book
customer_reviews.text: Very basic but also informative, Dave's YouTube videos are far better. But it covers basics. And that's enough to get you started. Mostly the five "C's" on how to get started. Like anything else the knowledge is not useful unless it is used. So practice makes perfect.
customer_reviews.author: Ronald Neely

customer_reviews.title: David Canterbury? What can I say?
customer_reviews.text: Ever since I saw this guy cut himself open about half an inch, calmly, then shove in gunpowder, and light it to cauterize the wound I have been sold on just about everything he does. The quality of the book is better than what I expected with the waxy cover that feels like it can take some abuse in the field, although Dave will tell ya to read it before you need it! Awesome buy!
customer_reviews.author: Joel De La Vega

customer_reviews.title: Good to know stuff
customer_reviews.text: I grew up camping, fishing, hunting, etc., so much of the stuff is back to the future. But, all these books would be excellent to introduce the younger generation to how to survive. You may never need the knowledge, but knowledge is power when you to need to survive.
customer_reviews.author: Murray J Thompson

customer_reviews.title: Good gift for outdoorsmen of varying ages
customer_reviews.text: This is a nice book. It’s paperback but a nice paperback. Seems to be. Well-written book that I’m hoping my nephew enjoys. I didn’t read too much of it but it seems to be informative and insightful and written in clear simple language that a 10 year old would have no trouble with.
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer

customer_reviews.title: REVIEW OF BUSHCRAFT 101.
customer_reviews.text: This book is OK...there are several things which Dave doesn't cover such that it's easy to understand, and there are a few errors in the book. For example: there is a drawing showing a snare with a lock...the lock is not shown. There are some areas which he talks about but doesn't relly explain all that good. I know Dave is good at survival, but it seems the book was either written in haste, or the editing was poor.
customer_reviews.author: Susan Schena

customer_reviews.title: Cover is beautiful- book pretty useless
customer_reviews.text: Sorry to sound harsh but this out of date by a generation or two, obvious stuff, rambling, etc. if you want to learn bush craft for real use this will not be satisfying . It’s like talking with a 100 year old pioneer guy, charming but advice is not so useful
customer_reviews.author: greg kiger

customer_reviews.title: A good book written by one of America's most experienced bushcrafters
customer_reviews.text: A good book written by one of America's most experienced bushcrafters. This book is just what the title states: Bushcraft 101. If you are new to the whole bushcrafting scene, this book is a perfect beginner's guide to start out with. Need help selecting a type of knife? Not sure where to set up camp? Need to know the difference between a lashing and a knot? Want to know how to construct the perfect debris hut? Not sure how long to boil your water/food? These are the types of things Dave writes on...If you're already fairly versed on some of these basics, Advanced Bushcraft might be more up your alley.
customer_reviews.author: Doc

customer_reviews.title: Too basic, nothing in-depth or how-to
customer_reviews.text: This book would be a good choice for someone who is completely new to camping, hiking, and bushcraft--someone who is seeking an introductory explanation about what these things are. There are almost no "how-to" or instructional segments in this book. While there are plenty of illustrations, very few are instructional and the book relies mostly on verbal explanations rather than informative diagrams.
customer_reviews.author: James

customer_reviews.title: Decent Read
customer_reviews.text: Most of the information in here is pretty basic. If you were ever a boyscout you probably have a good grasp of most of this. It is a good read for a refresher though, and you will definately pick up some new knowlage throughout the book! I would recomend anyone planning on spending prolonged periods in the wilderness read this... you never know when you might need it!
customer_reviews.author: Badger

customer_reviews.title: Spend your money on something else.
customer_reviews.text: I am looking for something basic since I don't have the skills in the wilderness / survival but even with my lack of experience I found a lot of the teaching very elementary even for me. I won't say that I hate it however I wouldn't recommend it to anyone , I plan to show this book to my sister and I know she won't even be impressed.
customer_reviews.author: Rick

customer_reviews.title: A few places it would be nice to have a few more illustrations to help explain ...
customer_reviews.text: I am enjoying reading this book. Very informative for someone who has not studied up on these topics before. A few places it would be nice to have a few more illustrations to help explain what the author is describing, but I think if you get out and get your hands dirty so to speak, you would figure out what he means by actually working through the setup as you read it. Overall it is very easy to understand, and the illustrations that are in the book are very clarifying.
customer_reviews.author: Eric S.

customer_reviews.title: It's a book about dealing with the outdoors.
customer_reviews.text: Haven't had a chance to sit down and read this cover to cover yet, but I did skim through it. Good information but there's too much writing and not enough illustrations. Should be more illustrations of camp craft with written information about how that was accomplished. Good information so it is very useful.
customer_reviews.author: Robert Gosse

customer_reviews.title: Nice well rounded PRIMER on the skills
customer_reviews.text: Nice well rounded PRIMER on the skills, materials and knowledge that you will need for surviving in the wilderness. It reminds me of early 1900's books on traveling and outdoor camping. Nice few illustrations, but I think that more illustrations will make it better. It has too many words in it to be a field guide. A field guide must be informative concise and precise as well as properly illustrated.
customer_reviews.author: AWOL

customer_reviews.title: Bushcraft is important information for hunters, fishers, and wilderness hikers.
customer_reviews.text: This book covers the basic knowledge to know how to be safe and enjoy my time in the wilderness. I do go in the forest and wilderness areas a lot, so I have to know. One topic is next, Bushcraft first-aid, problems may come up and I have to know how to fix them.
customer_reviews.author: Edward Sedelmeier

customer_reviews.title: Not A bad book good to have
customer_reviews.text: Good book but missing better explanations for some of the different skills he’s tryin to teach from different knots to shelters just not enough illustrations and not explained great but overall a good book to have and I’m happy I purchased it
customer_reviews.author: Ed

customer_reviews.title: Not for the experienced outdoorsman.
customer_reviews.text: This book is for people with no prior experiences. I was disappointed with the lack of illustration for the presented ideas. A book written with the average woodsman experience I would like to think. Basically a remedial course for those of us who have grown up in rural settings. I cannot truly recommend this as a must read.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew M.

customer_reviews.title: Useful book
customer_reviews.text: This book has helped me so much in my desire to start bushcraft. I have used it every time I buy a piece of gear, I look to see what the book suggests about that specific type of gear. It does seem pretty basic at times but it is an intro book after all. I plan on buying the advanced bushcraft book since I enjoyed this one so much.
customer_reviews.author: Pablo

customer_reviews.title: Good book of basics
customer_reviews.text: I wish it had more practical step by step instructions for building things out of wood at camp. And better basics of plant and tree identification. YouTube has helped my bushcraft skills for free far more than this book has. Nice cover though.
customer_reviews.author: QuestionSwami

customer_reviews.title: Great for learning the basics!
customer_reviews.text: Love this book!!!!!!! I have learned so much from it. I just started reading into the survival stuff recently and was looking for something to start off with. This was perfect for someone who is wanting to being to learn survival skills. I highly recommend this if you think that this is something you might want to get into.
customer_reviews.author: Vanessa sherriff

customer_reviews.title: Seems like he knows what he's talking about
customer_reviews.text: I was surprised that in not a word was written about how when you process an animal to eat you MUST remove the gall bladder. He suggests eating the liver, but you can't eat the liver of any animal without first removing the gall bladder carefully. It's not enough to say "clean out the innards", if the gall bladder bursts, your dinner is ruined. Birds have crops to remember to empty, and they also have gall bladders that must be removed prior to eating the birds or their very tasty livers. Incomplete information. Seems like he knows what he's talking about, but just not about processing game.
customer_reviews.author: Crisol

customer_reviews.title: Great beginner book.
customer_reviews.text: If you're into, or want to get into bushcraft, this book is a must. It's easy to follow, and full of great info. This will teach about the history of bushcraft, the gear you need and don't need, and has easy to follow illustrations and instructions on a ton of basic bushcraft skills.
customer_reviews.author: Kyle

customer_reviews.title: A MUST have survival book!
customer_reviews.text: Don't let bad reviews stop you from buying this like it did me. Now in 2017 I finally bought it, and so glad I did. This book is GOLD.!!! It was a wealth of knowledge in it. I hate that I didn't get it sooner. I couldn't put it down, read it all in 3 days. If you want to increase your knowledge in survival, this book is amazing. I recommend the entire set.
customer_reviews.author: Brendon

customer_reviews.title: More like a copy of lots of other books than orginal work
customer_reviews.text: This book was written by Dave Canterbury. I point this out because I have mixed emotions about purchasing anything of his. Though I did buy this book. Fact is 70% of the information in this book is common knowledge to old Boy Scouts, avid outdoors-men, hunters, fisherman, etc. He does have some recipes in the back of the book. Even the pictures look like the picture that come up in Google when you Google things like tinder, etc. I would only recommend this book to people who are clueless, fans of Dave Canterbury, young Boy Scouts,
customer_reviews.author: Tropical Tom

customer_reviews.title: here is a book that breaks down the basics and ...
customer_reviews.text: here is a book that breaks down the basics and widely accepted and used practices. Lots of outdoor projects that can be done by young and old. Some require processing branches and such and some are stored for urban backyard. To further aid you in learning the author has taught so many they pass the info along thru you videos on each topic. Well worth getting
customer_reviews.author: Bushcraft Joe

customer_reviews.title: Wonderful Resource for Survival Know-how
customer_reviews.text: This is an awesome resource for survival techniques, training, and crafts. I'm simply fascinated by this topic, and I foresee this book (rather, what I'll learn from it) being very helpful for any time I need it. I watched Dual Survival on the Discovery Channel when it was Dave Canterbury and Cody Lundin, and I enjoyed it, so when I was emailed recommendations from Amazon for this book (along with its sequel and the book Skulls), I readily decided to buy this book, and two others.
customer_reviews.author: Brian C. Maloney

customer_reviews.title: Essential for Bushcrafters
customer_reviews.text: This one had been on my list for ages. Finally got it. Despite owning a dozen or so manuals and guides, I still found new and relevant information in this text. It is a far better comprehensive guide than most.
customer_reviews.author: KC Ramsey

customer_reviews.title: while this expects you to use some basic modern tools ...
customer_reviews.text: while this expects you to use some basic modern tools (knife, hand axe) vs total 'survivalist'. it will teach you there is more than driving your Lexus to a KOA, loaded down with everything the sales person at Dicks said you had to buy, when it comes to camping outdoors. Just kidding :) But it does give you real skills to build on. Think of it as an adult version of the boy scout manual and your in the ball park.
customer_reviews.author: A. Stover

customer_reviews.title: You like the outdoors - this book is for you
customer_reviews.text: Great read! If you spend anytime outdoors or with scouting - great items in here that makes it a super easy read - and enjoy content put into the book - I quickly purchased the advanced version (book 2) right after
customer_reviews.author: Matthew W Norton

customer_reviews.title: Great intro to bushcraft
customer_reviews.text: Dave Canterbury does a great job of getting out the basics of Bushcraft in this book. I would highly recommend this book to anyone that is thinking about picking up bushcraft in general or really to anyone that spends time in the outdoors at all. The field guide is truly set up as a baseline of wilderness survival that anyone spending time on a trail should at least have reviewed. This book also serves as great reference material as you mature in your bushcraft/outdoors skills. The book is also a very quick read. I only own the Kindle version but was happy with the format and diagrams.
customer_reviews.author: AG

customer_reviews.title: Well done!
customer_reviews.text: Great book Dave! I've not been able to put this down. Its a really great introduction to concepts of camping/hiking/bushcraft/etc.. Even more than the content in the book, I enjoy Canterbury's passion for the wilderness, which is very pronounced throughout the book. I feel like there is a bit of an underlying tone throughout this book. it encourages you to go outside, and try to find the things that work for you when you're in the bush. I wish that there was a little bit more depth in certain points, but then again I have not yet moved on to the next installment "Advanced Bushcraft".
customer_reviews.author: David M Buckholz

customer_reviews.title: Nice.
customer_reviews.text: Got as a gift for a friend but have been reading over before giving it and it seems very cool. Easy to read and look it. Easy to navigate. Don’t see how they couldn’t like it!
customer_reviews.author: K Loftis

customer_reviews.title: Learn to be Survivorman!
customer_reviews.text: Excellent book. Considering the times we are in, with the world on fire and the instability of our nation and its leadership, these are great skills to have. Some I know from my days in the scouts, some new.. All great information that may even save your LIFE...
customer_reviews.author: Nik Barry

customer_reviews.title: Great start for those who have little to no backcountry experience.
customer_reviews.text: Really a great refresh for someone who was born and raised in rural NC, and took boy scouts as a kid, although that is also my dislike with this book, it's really the core basics. And if you need a touch up or have never had any backcountry experience, this is a great starting point filled with practical info, common sense isn't so common, so this might be the book for you, if your looking to really further your survival skills and backcountry knowhow I would recommend one the US military issue survival guides.
customer_reviews.author: Dewydirts

customer_reviews.title: great tips on bush survival
customer_reviews.text: There are many usefuls tidbits, and some detailed methods, for being in the bush for any amount of time. Very useful as intended for a grandson in Colorado Rockies
customer_reviews.author: Senor Cambalache

customer_reviews.title: Really can't because it's all equally important.
customer_reviews.text: Well written book that covers pretty much everything to keep you alive. The book is not very in depth but it's considering the amount of topics that it covers. Good book for someone who already knows alittle.
customer_reviews.author: kenneth collins

customer_reviews.title: Bushcraft basics and more
customer_reviews.text: Great book with tons of useful information. Some of the tips and advice regarding what gear to get are a little outdated but still very relevant and applicable if you are looking to be very minimalist in what you buy and bring out there. All the information you need to get into the woods and "smooth it" (as Cantebury says) is in this book. It is a fairly comprehensive introduction to the hobby and offers many options/perspectives so it can be useful to many different people. It is also very easy to read and organized so different topics/answers can be found quickly.
customer_reviews.author: David C

customer_reviews.title: Boring
customer_reviews.text: I’m really interested in learning bushcraft and I’m sure this is a great resource, but, ugh, so boring.
customer_reviews.author: Tiny Violet

customer_reviews.title: A must-have book
customer_reviews.text: This book is an absolute necessity for any serious ( or novice ) backpacker, hiker, prepper, or nature lover - tons of info, some redundant, some not, but all important - easy read, some illustrations, and lotsa tips to make a day ( or night ) in the woods way more enjoyable
customer_reviews.author: ruski3:16

customer_reviews.title: Outdoor survival information
customer_reviews.text: I have Dave Canterbury other book and enjoyed it so much. When see an author whom I believe knows what he is talking about I get it. Give his books a read you may learn something new. Beside isn't that what books are for anyway.
customer_reviews.author: Russ

customer_reviews.title: Not the best for a beginner.
customer_reviews.text: This book has some basic information, but often times, it is not descriptive enough and leaves the reader confused. Illustrations and or photographs to correspond with the notation would have been helpful.
customer_reviews.author: LVMoxie

customer_reviews.title: Packed with so much information
customer_reviews.text: I am just into this read but have learn so much already!! Some things that have been forgotten and some new. HD book cover and very wear resistant and the pages are thick and tear resistant. High quality info and High Quality vehicle to deliver hundreds of useful tips and tricks in a very simple language to easily comprehend. Thank you!!! Its worth double the cost. But don't say anything to the publisher. :) Dan
customer_reviews.author: Dano

customer_reviews.title: Fair condition
customer_reviews.text: The book itself looks like it will be a good/helpful read...gifting to someone who loves camping. Disappointed that the bins seems creased and not new.
customer_reviews.author: Joslyn

customer_reviews.title: To get the most out of this book you will ...
customer_reviews.text: To get the most out of this book you will need to supplement it with other media because the diagrams found within Bushcraft 101 are limited. Topics are discussed briefly, and many don’t have any pictures that demonstrate exactly what Canterbury is talking about.
customer_reviews.author: Chris

customer_reviews.title: Great read for beginners and experienced bushcraft enthusiasts alike
customer_reviews.text: Love this book. It makes outdoorsmanship perfectly accessible for a beginner by highlighting very solid fundamentals that even the more experienced outdoorsman will benefit from being reminded of.
customer_reviews.author: Carlo C.

customer_reviews.title: Pan to bug out, "rough it", or prep for survival? This is a MUST READ.
customer_reviews.text: Recommend highly to anyone interested in outdoor craft! Having seen Mr. Canterbury on TV I was inspired to rethink my own woodcraft doctrine. While modern technology is great you can not overate bush craft (something I already valued). But after seeing Mr. Canterbury's minimalist techniques I wanted to absorb this doctrine myself and his book did not disappoint. If you are familiar with military survival doctrine I think you will love this book! It converted me to more of a minimalist and taught me to do more than just survive, and escape the wilderness. I will try a complete revamp of my bug out bag and my day to day minimal carry kit. Can't thank you enough Mr. Canterbury!!
customer_reviews.author: Jason T.

customer_reviews.title: Informative and complete
customer_reviews.text: From knots to building shelter and animal traps, this book has everything you need to survive in the bush (North American bush anyways - I don't know about tropical rain forests or African savannas). It's very easy instructive reading with lots of pictures. What more could you want from this type of instruction manual?
customer_reviews.author: Alex K

customer_reviews.title: Great Father’s Day book!
customer_reviews.text: We ordered this as a Father's day gift...Husband loved it. It great for basics and a good guide for sharing with the kids. We ordered the second book at the same time. They are both enjoyable for all ages. Great pictures, extremely useful information! Enjoy!
customer_reviews.author: Amanda Murphy

customer_reviews.title: More like bushcraft 95.  (college class level joke.  get it?)
customer_reviews.text: If you follow the information in this book, you'll probably have a very nice "woodsy" overnighter or weekend trip. It feels like the section on trapping goes into way more depth than any other bushcraft book I've read, though, so that was very nice.
customer_reviews.author: Carl Forgey

customer_reviews.title: Great Read and the Next Best Thing to Being There
customer_reviews.text: This is the kind of book you can sit down and enjoy on a winter evening and imagine putting the tips and information to use on those outdoor trips you are planning or just dreaming about. Just listen as Dave sits across the fire and offers his wealth of information on how to survive and enjoy the wilderness. Its even a joy to reread sections of particular interest when you have just a few minutes.
customer_reviews.author: Desertguy

customer_reviews.title: Bushcraft 101
customer_reviews.text: Dave Canterbury did an excellent job of putting this material together, I am impressed. Great material in a very orderly understandable format. However it would have been even better with more illustrations and pictures. Good work Dave.
customer_reviews.author: Comet Cowboy 46

customer_reviews.title: grandsons favorite author
customer_reviews.text: easy to read, knowledgeable and geared to a wide audience; my grandson is 18 and really into this new hobby, will look for more from this author
customer_reviews.author: diana a.

customer_reviews.title: Valuable info and very sturdy book. Thank you! :)
customer_reviews.text: So far, have only read the book, but it is very interesting and came in the mail very quickly. I like that the book is super sturdy and should last a long time.
customer_reviews.author: cynthia b. alvord

customer_reviews.title: They both brought very good points of view to the table in every circumstance
customer_reviews.text: I first heard of Dave Canterbury on "Dual Survival" and thought his dynamic with Cody Lundin was hysterical. They both brought very good points of view to the table in every circumstance. This book has provided me with a travel guide for when I go back country and need refreshers.... i'm definitely no expert, but i'll tell you this book has definitely helped in a lot of circumstances.
customer_reviews.author: mikeofthemountains

customer_reviews.title: Really enjoyed the read, educational
customer_reviews.text: I bought this book after watching shows like, Man vs. Wild and Naked and Afraid. You'll see that some of the subjects that are mentioned on the show are also mentioned in the book. Granted no one will gain experience from reading this book, but I'll bring the book along with me for all my future scheduled hikes and camping trips and I feel better knowing that I have a understanding of what to do if something goes wrong.
customer_reviews.author: Dsil

customer_reviews.title: Useful information
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this for my teen nephew who is very outdoorsy and he loved it. I own the whole set and love looking through all the information.
customer_reviews.author: JXF

customer_reviews.title: A great book to start with.
customer_reviews.text: This book was a gift to my son in law , for his birthday. I have watched Dave Canterbury for years , on these Survival shows on tv. Now if you go on youtube he is now teaching Bushcraft as only Dave can do it. I checked out this book myself before giving it to John. If you like the outdoors , camping hunting and wilderness survival. Then you might consider this book. Lots of learning between the covers. I think it's a must have.
customer_reviews.author: Doug Olsen

customer_reviews.title: Re-ignited my fire for the outdoors
customer_reviews.text: I have always been an avid outdoorsman (hunting, fishing, camping, etc). But this book has brought on a whole new desire to explore and become closer to nature. Also my son is getting to the age that he is more interested in the outdoors and this book has helped me in teaching and showing him new things for outdoor survival. Will definitely keep this book back to reference in the future and am looking forward to driving into the companion books as well
customer_reviews.author: Justin Hobbs

customer_reviews.title: Great for a true beginner....not for the moderate to advanced
customer_reviews.text: This book is exactly what it says 101. It would be perfect for the beginner. I should have taken that into consideration as I knew a lot of what was mentioned. I found myself skipping some chapters and trying to find new things to learn. That being said, it would be a great book for the beginner!
customer_reviews.author: Natasha

customer_reviews.title: Great!
customer_reviews.text: This book is pretty cool. It teaches you some pretty neat things that I think everyone should know! The book it's self is constructed very well and I feel like it would hold up for years to come! I would suggest this book to anyone! It's always good to learn new things! Shipping was fast and was in my mail box in no time!! Price was right also for what you get! Very happy with it! Would order from this seller again!
customer_reviews.author: amanda

customer_reviews.title: Great read. most of this book is the stuff ...
customer_reviews.text: Great read. most of this book is the stuff I had learned or came across in camping in my youth so it was a great reminder of those times. Certainly a great one to take and teach the kiddos on the survival basics when in the bush and camping in the woods like we did for short stretch's (3 or 4 days) without any gear. This is Texas though and the deserts are not as forgiving. I do recommend keeping the recipes section and practice those cooking techniques any time of the year or when the opportunity for those meals arise, just to get the taste.
customer_reviews.author: kgar

customer_reviews.title: This book is a great reference for anyone familiar with The Pathfinder System and ...
customer_reviews.text: I've been a fan of Dave and have been watching his YouTube videos since nearly the very beginning. It's been quite interesting to see the evolution of The Pathfinder System. This book is a great reference for anyone familiar with The Pathfinder System and indispensable to anyone desiring to start learning about wilderness self-reliance. The work that the Canterbury family and friends are doing to pass along the tribal/frontier knowledge is unparalleled, IMHO. I can't recommend this book highly enough.
customer_reviews.author: Rayf Horn

customer_reviews.title: My Outdoor Man Loves It
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my husband who loves the outdoors. We read through the entire thing in the first week and now he and my 5 year old son and spending many of their weekends learning and perfecting the skills the book teaches.
customer_reviews.author: Brandon & Cacia

product_meta.title: Bushcraft 101: A Field Guide to the Art of Wilderness Survival
